name: Student Taught Courses (StuCo): Intuitive Quantum Computing
base_name: Student Taught Courses (StuCo): Intuitive Quantum Computing
long_desc: This course covers the basic foundations of quantum computing through the use of visuals and examples. The goal is to build an intuitive understanding rather than depending on complex math that is often used for even the most basic quantum concepts. This course is ideal for those with a computer science background who are curious to learn about quantum computing fundamentals. No prior quantum computing experience is expected. A basic familiarity with linear algebra is helpful but not required.

custom_fields.goals: After taking this course, students should be able to comfortably discuss quantum computing topics, understand news about advancements in the field of quantum computing, as well as identify low quality generalizations about quantum computing. This course should leave a student with a strong conceptual baseline if they choose to take mathematically rigorous quantum courses in the future.
custom_fields.key_topics: Students will learn the basics of quantum computing, as well as some very simple quantum communication and quantum information theory.
custom_fields.assessment_structure:
40% Attendance
20% Required Readings
20% Midterm Project
20% Final Presentation
custom_fields.relevance: This course is designed for any student who is curious about quantum computing and wants a soft, visual introduction to the subject. To get the most out of the course, the student should have familiarity with computer science topics, since this course will be looking at quantum computing through the lens of computer science.
custom_fields.learning_resources:
Slides presented in each class will be available for students.
If possible, each class will be recorded via zoom or similar and be available as well.
A Piazza forum will be available for students to ask each other and instructor questions.
Weekly readings will be posted with some optional additional material from the following sources: Quantum Computing Since Democritus (by Scott Aaronson), Quantum in Pictures (by Bob Coecke & Stefano Gogioso), Shtetl-Optimized (Scott Aaronson's Blog), Algorithmic Assertions Blog (Craig Gidney's blog).
custom_fields.extra_time_commitment:
Each week there will be an assigned short reading that is illustrative of the upcoming lecture.
This reading should take no more than 1 hour per week.
Students are expected to participate on the Piazza and answer each others' questions, which should take less than 1 hour per week.
The midterm project and final presentation are each expected to take roughly 8 hours of work.
